title: Delta Airlines Is Making a Surprise Move to Expand in the Americas
text:
Text size

U.S. air carrier Delta Air Lines is taking a big stake in Latam Airlines to expand its presence in the Americas.

The surprise move has shares of Latam soaring. It’s good for Delta too, and consistent with its global strategy, bringing the big U.S. carrier more scale throughout North and South America.

“This transformative partnership with Latam will bring together our leading global brands, enabling us to provide the very best service and reliability for travelers to, from and throughout the Americas,” Delta CEO Ed Bastian said in the company’s news release. On a combined basis, the two airlines will hold leading market share in five of the top six Latin American markets.

Latam stock (ticker: LTM) was up 31% in recent trading to $11.83. Delta (DAL) shares edged higher. That reaction makes sense. Latam is a $4 billion air carrier and Delta is valued at more than $38 billion. What’s more, Delta will pay $1.9 billion for 20% of Latam, valuing the company at $16 per share. The LTM depository receipts closed Thursday at $9.01. Delta will also directly invest $350 million in Latam and join its board of directors.

In reaction to the news, J.P. Morgan Latin American transportation analyst Fernando Abdalla upgraded shares of Latam from the equivalent of Sell to Hold. “We become more constructive on the case post the unexpected announcement of a partnership with Delta,” wrote Abdalla in a Friday research report. “Delta can positively influence Latam like it did with [ GOL Linhas Aereas Inteligentes ].”

Delta has a 9% stake in GOL Linhas Aereas Inteligentes (GOL), a Brazilian airline.

Jamie Baker, the U.S. airline analyst at J.P. Morgan, says exerting influence over smaller carriers has been a cornerstone of Delta’s global strategy. He believes, like Abdalla, Delta’s involvement in Latam will yield “significant benefits” for the Latin American carrier.

The announcement will supercharge the stock performance of Latam. Its shares were down 4% year to date as of Thursday’s closing price. Delta, on the other hand, has had a good year, returning more than 20%, better than the 17% gain of the Dow Jones Industrial Average over the same span.

Baker rates shares of Delta the equivalent of a Buy with a $78 price target. More than 75% of analysts covering the company rate shares buy. The average buy rating ratio for stock in the Dow, for comparison, is about 55%.

Write to Al Root at allen.root@dowjones.com
description: Latam Airlines stock is soaring after Delta announced it would pay $1.9 billion for a 20% stake in South America’s biggest airline.
